thread.title: Devon MP Johnny Mercer rules himself out of race to be next Prime Minister

author: Patrick Phelvin
title: Devon MP Johnny Mercer rules himself out of race to be next Prime Minister
text:
Devon MP Johnny Mercer rules himself out of race to be next Prime Minister As speculation mounts over leadership role, Plymouth's member of Parliament says he's too inexperienced to run Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Share 
Plymouth MP Johnny Mercer has denied that he has ambitions to be Prime Minister. Mr Mercer was interviewed on Sky News at lunchtime, after Theresa May used a visit to Japan to issue a defiant message that she is not a “quitter” and will lead the party into the 2022 general election. 
Mr Mercer, the Conservative MP for Plymouth Moor View, said he was pleased with the Prime Minister’s announcement “because we need to deliver stability”. 
He said Theresa May was a good Prime Minister, but conceded that the last general election campaign was not a good one, “and she was in charge”. 
“The Theresa May I speak to privately is very different to the one that I see in public on the television. 
“I do think she’s over-coached. Read More Exeter University accused of exploiting 'zero hours' workers 
“If she was to really relax into it and be herself she could be a success. If she gets a good deal from Brexit for this country ... there is a path where she could stay on and be a good Prime Minister. 
“There is also a path where the party say the last election was a disaster and we want someone else. 
“She says she wants to carry on. I’m pleased she does.” 
Sky News presenter Dermot Murnaghan asked Mr Mercer, the Conservative MP for Plymouth Moor View, whether he would take his chance. 
“If the ball comes out of the scrum, would you be one of those looking to pick it up?” he asked. Read More 
Mr Mercer replied: “No. I’ve been an MP for five minutes. There are a lot of things I want to achieve and there a lot of people who are better than me. 
“It’s not something I ever think about. 
“I’ve got a good seat here in Plymouth that I need to work hard to retain. Read More
